parts: Identify this type of through-composed, polyphonic song which originated in Italy in the 1500s. Composers often chose love or pastoral poems for the texts.
This Italian composer completed nine books of madrigals which showcase his movement from 16th century polyphony to the new style of the baroque. He's probably better known for his work in opera.

This Italian nobleman also lived around the turn of the 17th century and published six books of madrigals, some of which display an unusually unstable tonality. Also known for his Sacre Cantiones, this man may or may not have been affected by killing his wife and her lover.
Identify this effect in which crossing two different mutants causes recovery of the wild-type phenotype.

In bacteria, another form of complementation testing involves using these small circular genetic elements discovered by Lederberg. The R one is used to transfer antibiotic resistance between organisms.
The F plasmid, which is necessary for conjugation, codes for the components of this structure. These small projections are used to transfer genetic material from one bacterium to another.
Name this play in which Corporal Lestrade arrests Makak on an unnamed island in the West Indies.

This poem by the author of Dream on Monkey Mountain tells of the fishermen Achille and Hector and their battle for the affections of Helen as well as the story of Plunkett and Maud who live on the same island.
This St. Lucian author wrote both Dream on Monkey Mountain and the epic poem Omeros.

answers: Cryovolcanism [or Cryovolcano; prompt on Ice Volcano or anything implying a volcano that is cold]
parts: Name this cold form of eruption, usually observed on moons which has been hypothesized to happen on Pluto and other Kuiper Belt objects. It resembles a geyser more than its earthly namesake.

In 2005, Cassini detected Cryovolcanism during a flyby of this non-Titan moon of Saturn.The pure water ejected in its cryovolcanic eruption has led scientists to believe there could be an ocean underneath the surface.
The first body to be detected undergoing cryovolcanism is Triton, a moon of this planet. It has the highest winds in the Solar system and is home to the Great Dark Spot and Scooter.
Name this event in which Doom addicts and Marilyn Manson fans Dylan Klebold and Eric Harris killed several students at a high school in Littleton, Colorado.

Klebold and Harris were initially believed to be part of this clique of misfits at Columbine, named for their style of dress. Turns out they were only friends with one member of the group, Chris Morris.

This other school shooting was committed by a shopkeeper named Thomas Hamilton in a Scottish town in 1996. Afterwards, the Snowdrop Petition succeeded in banning most private handgun ownership in Britain.

answers: Fra Angelico or Guido di Pietro
parts: Identify this ubiquitous scene in Christian art, which depicts the archangel Gabriel informing Mary that she will have a son.

Gabriel looks rather displeased in the annunciation scene from this triptych by Matthias Grunewald. The original work has been split into three, and the first view is a particularly gruesome crucifixion.

In one of this man's versions of the annunciation, which is set in a portico, Gabriel and Mary have their arms crossed in identical positions. That work, like his San Marco Altarpiece and many others, is housed in St. Mark's in Florence. He also did an Adoration of the Magi in collaboration with Fra Filippo Lippi.

answers: nuclear weapons or nukes [accept alternatives for "nuclear" such as "atomic," "fission," or "thermonuclear"; accept alternatives for "weapons" such as "bombs," "warheads," "missiles," etc.]
John Diefenbaker [accept Dief the Chief; prompt on "Dief"]
North Atlantic Treaty Organization or NATO [accept Organisation du traitÃ© de l'Atlantic nord or OTAN]
parts: France's Force de Frappe and China's Second Artillery Corps use these devices that were tested in during Ivy Mike and Castle Bravo. The Non-Proliferation Treaty tries to stop their spread of these WMDs.
This world leader accepted American Bomarc missiles onto his country's soil but only equipped with conventional warheads. He also controversially scrapped the Avro Arrow program.

Nuclear warfare nearly broke out after this entity engaged in highly realistic simulations of nuclear warfare preparation in Able Archer 83 exercises. This organization invoked Article 5 of its charter for the first time after the September 11 attacks.
Name this curvaceous glassy modern art museum located in the capital of Biscay in Basque country. It is the counterpart to another museum located on 5th avenue.
The Guggenheim-Bilbao was designed by this modern architect, who recently got into trouble for his Stata Center at MIT being a mold magnet. He also designed the Walt Disney Concert Hall.

In front of the Guggenheim-Bilbao is a large multicolored sculpture of a puppy made from steel and flowers. That sculpture is by this American artist, who also uses balloon animals as the basis for his steel sculptures.

answers: The Human Comedy [or La Comedie humaine]
parts: Name this series of novels and short stories that includes Cousin Bette and Eugenie Grandet.
This realist French author wrote The Human Comedy, which includes a novel involving Eugene de Rastignac, Le Pere Goriot.

his other character from Le Pere Goriot is nicknamed the "Cheater of Death" and arranges the murder of Victorine's brother so that Eugene can acquire her family's wealth. He also appears in an eponymous play by Balzac.
Name this retired professor from UC Santa Cruz who was blacklisted by J Edgar Hoover. She's also argued that the penal system heavily resembles slavery.
Angela Davis was a member of this Marxist African-American political party, which was partly founded by Bobby Seale. Its ideology was embodied in a Ten-point program.
This other founder of the Black Panther Party was shot to death by Tyrone Robinson in 1989. He was imprisoned for the shooting of police officer John Frey, but was later released.
Name this quantity important in economics, which is the amount of satisfaction gained from the consumption of a single unit of a good or service.

Smith's The Wealth of Nations discusses an paradox of marginal utility about this substance. The paradox states that water is cheap yet necessary for life, while these objects are very expensive but largely ornamental.

Carl Menger's Principles of Economics was an early treatment of marginal utility. Menger founded this school of economics, which advocates using praxeology instead of mathematical or statistical methods.
Identify this Platonic dialogue in which the title individual recounts to Echecrates the last hours of Socrates' life.
The Phaedo is one of the main sources for Plato's philosophy of these entities, which remain always perfect and unchanging, and of which particular examples are merely imperfect instantiations.

A similar defense of the immortality of the soul is found in the Phaedo of this philosopher, a close friend of Gotthold Lessing who was involved in a controversy over Lessing's supposed deathbed conversion to pantheism.

answers: Stopping Voltage [or Stopping Potential or anything that hints that there is a potential stopping the electrons]
Cross Section [Do not accept Cross sectional area as there is no direct correlation between interaction cross section and area.]
parts: Name this effect explained by Albert Einstein in one of his Annus Mirabilis papers. It occurs when light with energy  above the work function of a metal knocks namesake particles off of a plate of that metal.

In order to measure the energy of the ejected photoelectrons, a charged plate is be placed near the emitter. This is the point at which the work done by the repulsive force equals the energy of the electrons.

This quantity for the Photoelectric effect is directly proportional to the 5th power power of the atomic number and inversely proportional to about the cube of frequency, and it describes the probability of  the effect occurring.

answers: Natural Theology ; or, Evidence of the Existence and Attributes of the Deity, Collected from the appearances of Nature
parts: Name this Anglican Priest and  English Philosopher who wrote A view of the Evidence of Christianity and the aforementioned book  which is subtitled Evidences of the Existence and Attributes of the Deity.
This book, Paley's most famous,  introduced the analogy of the watchmaker. It is also the name for a branch of theology which is based on the "fifth way" of the Summa theologica.

The watchmaker view of God was advanced by this religious group who proposed that after "designing the watch" God left it free to run on its own. Famous members include Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Franklin.

answers: Muhammed ibn Musa al-Khwarizmi or Algoritmi
parts: Identify this caliph who was advised by the Barmakid family. Among his more famous actions was creating the House of Wisdom in Baghdad.

Harun Al-Rashid was the fifth caliph of this empire, which succeeded the Umayyad caliphate after winning the Battle of the Zab River. It lost a great deal of power after Hulagu Khan's sack of Baghdad.
Among the members of the House of Wisdom is this early mathematician, who is probably most famous for deriving the quadratic formula and basically inventing algebra.

Identify this supreme Hindu deity and member of the Trimurti along with Shiva and Brahma. This preserver deity has 10 avatars, the last of which heralds doomsday and the eighth of which is the blue-skinned Krishna.
Vishnu is sometimes depicted as reclining on Seshat, who is the king of these creatures. The winged Garuda is the mortal enemy of this race of gigantic serpents.
This brother of Krishna is sometimes said to be the avatar of Seshat. During the Mahabharata, this man taught Bhima how to fight with a mace.
Identify this structure which is held together by the strong force. It consists of protons and neutrons, and those that contain a magic number of substituents are unusually stable.

To find the binding energy of the nucleus, one uses the E equals m c squared formula on this quantity, which is the difference between the actual mass of a nucleus and the summed mass of its substituents.
Seaborg hypothesized that nuclei with somewhere around 110 protons and 190 neutrons would have unusually long lifespans. Said collection of elements is said to occupy this geographically-named place.

answers: A Week on the Concord and Merrimack Rivers
parts: Name the location in the woods of Concord to which the author moved because he "wished to live deliberately, to front only the essential facts of life."
Thoreau also wrote this work after his brother died from tetanus. It is a travelogue about a boat trip through the Northeast.
Alec Therien, a French Canadian visitor whose simplicity and connection to nature is admired by Thoreau, was a member of this profession.
Name this city in which 7 popes resided during its namesake papacy and in which a second line of illegitimate popes reigned during the Great Western Schism.
Following the Failed Council of Pisa where the popes of Rome and Avignon both refused to step down, Sigismund called for this council which deposed the three reigning popes and executed Jan Hus.
After deposing the three simultaneous popes, the Council of Constance elected this legitimate successor who moved his court to Rome.
Name the play in which Vivie leaves her mother because she disapproves of her mother's source of wealth.
Mrs. Warren's Profession was written by this Irish playwright who also penned Arms and the Man and Back to Methuselah.
Shaw frequently quarreled with this man who wrote about Gabriel Syme in the novel The Man Who Was Thursday. This man also wrote the poem The Ballad of the White Horse about a Saxon king.
